pullRequest.title: [bluetooth] Changed characteristic read/write to use CompletableFutures
pullRequest.bodyText:
This PR is mostly a refactoring of the characteristic logic so that CompletableFuture is used instead of the listener callback.
There quite a few benefits to this:

It makes it possible for developers to properly associate a given read/write task with the success/failure handling logic. Currently if multiple read/write requests occurred for the same characteristic it was not possible to identify which request a particular callback was for. This PR fixes that.
Allows for better handling/reporting of exceptions that occur during asynchronous characteristic processes. The old methods would only return a boolean which would not let callers know how something failed, only that it failed. Using a CompletableFuture allows BluetoothDevice implementations to return failure details that were otherwise not available.

As part of this change to use CompletableFuture it made sense to separate the read/write characteristic data from the characteristics themselves since it was much cleaner for the read characteristic future to return the data rather than the characteristic. A positive byproduct of this is that it also fixes concurrency issues that I've begun to see when a characteristic is written to at the same time an update notification occurs.
The characteristic data formatting code has been migrated to a new utility class BluetoothUtils.
Additional features:

Initial contribution of the connectOnDemand feature for ConnectedBluetoothHandler implementations. This is an alternate connection mode where instead of a constant connection it will only attempt to establish a connection when a characteristic is read/written to. A disconnect occurs after a configured idle time. This is useful for devices which would only be communicated with periodically and/or cannot support a constant connection. Thus would allow the device to save energy.

Fixes: #6935
Signed-off-by: Connor Petty mistercpp2000+gitsignoff@gmail.com
